metadata.case_name: General Assurance Society Ltd. v. Chandmull Lal Chand

facts.text: Town of Dhulian situated on banks of Ganges, river changing course for several years, in 1949 part of town washed away.

Respondents submitted proposals to appellant insurance company on June 2, 1950 to insure houses in Dhulian (Holding Nos. 274, 274/A-B-C-D and 273, 273/A-B-C-D) for Rs. 51,000 and Rs. 65,000 against fire including cyclone, flood, change of course of river, erosion, landslides, subsidence.

On June 3, 1950, company accepted proposals by letters stating assured covered under cover numbers enclosed, with endorsement at back: 'Including Cyclone, Flood and or loss by change of course of river diluvium and or Erosion of River Landslide and or subsidence. It is further noted that there is a thatched building of residence within 50 ft. of the above premises.'

Cover notes dated June 5, 1950 (interim protection Nos. 118848 and 118850) held property insured for 30 days from June 3, 1950 to June 3, 1951 against fire subject to proposal terms and usual conditions of Society's policies, expressly for 30 days only, terminable by policy delivery or declinature.
Dispute whether cover notes enclosed with acceptance letters of June 3.
On June 7, 1950, assured sent premiums by cheque.
On July 1, 1950, assured wrote asking for policy or extension of cover notes (Ex. Ag).

Houses 400/450 feet from river bank on June 2, 1950, river calm till second week of June; began to rise third week, no erosion till end of June; erosion started last week of June affecting houses 10-50 ft from bank; on July 15, 250 ft away.
P.K. Ghose (DW 2) visited Dhulian on June 18, 1950 for local inquiries on behalf of company.
Erosion started 4-5 days after Rathajatra (around June 20, 1950).
On July 6, 1950, company wrote cancelling risk from that date in accordance with inspection report, endorsement under preparation.
On July 15, 1950, assured replied that company bound as erosion had commenced, no time to reinsure.
On July 17, 1950, company prepared and sent endorsement cancelling insurance from July 6, 1950, refunding pro rata premium.
Assured replied cancellation invalid as risk commenced.
Company referred to Condition 10 of Fire Policy allowing termination at option on notice.
On August 2, assured said Condition 10 applies only to fire risk, not after risk commenced.
Houses washed away on August 13 and 15, 1950.
Assured demanded payment unsuccessfully, filed suit in Calcutta High Court Original Side.
Single Judge (G.K. Mitter J.) dismissed suit with costs, holding Condition 10 applied to all risks.
Division Bench (P.B. Mukharji and S.K. Datta JJ.) reversed, decreed claim for Rs. 1,10,000 with costs and 3% interest.
High Court certified fit for appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether terms and conditions of the standard fire policy, including Condition 10, were incorporated into the contract of insurance via proposals, letters of acceptance, and cover notes.
Whether Condition 10 applied to risks beyond fire (cyclone, flood, etc.).
Whether Condition 10 is a usual condition and reasonable.
Whether cancellation on July 6, 1950 was valid or after risk had commenced or become inevitable.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cover notes accompanied or were sent with acceptance letters; incorporated terms of standard policy including Condition 10 allowing termination at option.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Usual conditions of Society's policies; Sun Fire Office v. Hart

petitioner_arguments.text: Condition 10 applies to all risks covered; mutual right to cancel at any time without reasons.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Condition 10 of Fire Policy; Central Bank of India Ltd. v. Hartford Fire Insurance Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cancellation valid as no erosion or imminent loss on July 6; houses 400-500 ft away.

respondent_arguments.text: Cover notes not enclosed with June 3 letters (dated June 5); letters accepted risk for full year without referring to policy conditions.
Condition 10 applies only to fire risk, not extended risks; not a 'usual condition'; unreasonable.
Cancellation invalid after risk commenced (erosion started end June); no time to reinsure.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd.

court_reasoning.text: Whether cover notes enclosed immaterial; letters of acceptance and cover notes together form contract incorporating standard policy terms including Condition 10 for full period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cover notes integral part; terms of policy govern even before issuance.

court_reasoning.text: Condition 10 applies to all risks; is usual condition in fire policies extended to other perils.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited in standard texts and precedents; mutual right.

court_reasoning.text: Condition 10 reasonable; no need for reasons or court scrutiny; insurers best judges of business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Sun Fire Office and Hartford cases.

court_reasoning.text: Cancellation on July 6 valid; no evidence risk commenced or inevitable (houses 400-500 ft away, erosion end June at 20-25 ft/day, calm till mid-June).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loss not imminent; falls within rule permitting cancellation before liability commences.

holdings.text: Contract incorporates standard fire policy terms including Condition 10 applicable to all risks.
Condition 10 usual and reasonable, allows cancellation at will without reasons.
Cancellation valid as risk not commenced or inevitable on July 6, 1950.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sun Fire Office v. Hart Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Condition allowing termination at will valid without reasons; insurers judge business prudence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. Hartford Fire Insurance Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar Condition 10 upheld even after riots; common term, reasonable.
Preliminary contract valid if essentials agreed; presumes usual policy terms.

precedents_cited.case_name: General Accident Insurance Corporation v. Cronk
precedents_cited.relevance: Proposal taken as for ordinary policy form.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Not applicable to cut down width of mutual cancellation clause.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Calcutta High Court Division Bench reversed; suit of respondents dismissed; High Court decree set aside as company within rights under Condition 10 to cancel policy before risk commenced.

key_quotes.text: This insurance may also at any time be terminated at the option of the Society, on notice to that effect being given to the Insured...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of Condition 10 central to dispute.

key_quotes.text: The words in which the power of determination is expressed... import that... nothing is required except the existence of a desire, on the part of the insurers, to get rid of future liability...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Privy Council upholding broad cancellation right.

key_quotes.text: Cancellation is reasonably possible before the liability under the policy has commenced or has become inevitable and it is a question of fact in each case...
key_quotes.speaker: court
